speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Kin selection and multilevel selection are alternative approaches for studying the evolution of social behavior, the relation between which has long been a source of controversy.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Many recent theorists regard the two approaches as ultimately equivalent, on the grounds that gene frequency change can be correctly expressed using either.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: however this shows only that the two are formally equivalent not that they offer equally good causal representations of the evolutionary process this article articulates the notion of an adequate causal representation using causal graphs and then seeks to identify circumstances under which kin and multi-level selection do and do not satisfy the test of causal adequacy

text: Nice abstract.

text: So the basic idea in 5.1 is simple, according to Akasha.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: A decomposition of evolutionary change is causally adequate if and only if the statistical associations that appear in the components reflect direct causal influences between the variables in question.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so one can imagine that there's two ways in which that decomposition can fail to be causally adequate.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: They're basically false positives and false negatives.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The first is you could have statistical associations that are spurious.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's an edge between variables that are not actually involved in a causal influence, like changing one wouldn't directly change the other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Or secondly, you might have statistical associations between variables that only indirectly causally influence each other.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the meaning of indirect will be coming clear.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So to make this graphical and have a visual intuition, Akasha writes, the ideas are best illustrated by using causal graphs or path diagrams.

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: More generally, they can be considered in a mutual information framework, but we want to reduce
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: our false positive causal assertions, spurious findings, and our false negative causal assertions.
